Own a shotgun for home defense, since that's what the founding fathers intended. Four employees break into my mansion. "What the Santa?!" As I grab my hat and sawed off off the fireplace mantle. Blow several holes through the first man, he's dead on the spot. Fire my second barrel on the second man, miss him entirely because he is him and nails the neighbor's thumper. I have to resort to the turret mounted at the top of the stairs loaded with jolly intent, "Tally ho lads" the bullets shred two men in the haze of projectiles, the sound set off the last mans screams. Reload and charge the last terrified rapscallion. He blows up stepping on a landmine as he runs through a dark hallway. Just as the founding fathers intended.

This game is great. It doesn't embody the regular jumpscare jpeg experience for most horror games and it instead puts you in the shoes of a person (optionally with a group of friends or randoms). It creates great moments to bond with random people and have funny and enjoyable moments in-game. I would highly recommend this game to those horror geeks and adrenaline junkies alike. It TERRIFIES you and it gets you ENGAGED in the game.

Normally first person player games make me queasy and this one isn't any different. However I do enjoy this game with its old style graphics and near same layout of every abandoned  place to explore. Once you get the hang of all the tell's for when monsters are around the scare factor still increases a bit because you never know what type of monster is lurking. It can get frustrating from time to time with how often you can and do die. sometimes worlds spawn and loot is harder to come by on the lower difficulty. All in all its a fun game to play with friends

There are pros and cons;

[b] Pros; [/b] 
Very Memeable, Not THAT scary (But it can be at times)

Very good if you have friends, or risk online (There can be 10 year olds at times which is a con)

The Yippee Bug.

Pressing the bell at the company when your friends are trying to sell stuff so they all die :3

[b] Cons; [/b] 
No friends means not a lot of fun,

You cannot recreate memes if you have no friends. (I cannot recreate memes :steamsad:)

Online can be annoying as there are people with hacks at times, hidden mods that are client side and not server side (Meaning someone can have a mod without anyone else needing it)

Online is also annoying at times because of A: Echo, and B: Children with microphones (mostly echoey)

The Forest Giant. (Eats your head)
The Thumper. (Eats your toes)
Eyeless Dogs. (Waiter! Waiter! Another mechanical keyboard user please!!)


Overall, I have 22.2 hours on this game and I have not regretted spending ¬£8.50 on it, so I think you should buy it personally if you like horror but also like dying unexpectedly and laughing about it afterward.

If you do buy the game because of this review, Welcome to the Company!
If you don't buy the game because of the review, That's okay too.

I however, bought this game FOR THE COMPANY!!!!

This is the end of my half shitpost, half realistic review of Lethal Company, thank you for reading, and don't miss quota.

[b] > Be me, just your average Joe, hoping to strike gold in the world of cooperative horror on Steam. üöÄ

> Enter Lethal Company, the game everyone's been buzzing about. Promises of adrenaline-pumping scavenger hunts and heart-stopping monster encounters had me hyped. üíÄüí∞

> But boy, oh boy, was I in for a disappointment. üò§

> Let's break it down, shall we?

> 1. **Low amount of content**: You'd think an intergalactic scavenger hunt would be jam-packed with variety, right? Wrong. Instead, we're treated to a handful of planet exteriors and a few interior rooms slapped together randomly. üåéüè† Stuff starts repeating faster than a broken record, leaving you wondering if you're stuck in some cosmic Groundhog Day.

> 2. **Boring gameplay loop**: Land, loot, run from monsters, repeat. Sounds thrilling, doesn't it? Well, it's about as exciting as watching paint dry in slow motion. No real challenge, just a game of luck. Either you make it out unscathed or end up as monster chow. Oh, and forget about fighting back‚Äîshovels are your best bet, but even that's a joke. üòí

> 3. **Lack of global progression**: Ever feel like you're running on a hamster wheel with no end in sight? That's Lethal Company for you. Quotas increase until you inevitably fail, and then poof! Your save is wiped, and you're back to square one. Talk about a slap in the face. üîÑüíî

> 4. **Graphics that make you want to claw your eyes out**: Ever seen a game that looks like it was designed by a toddler with a crayon? Well, welcome to Lethal Company. The low-poly aesthetic might've been charming in 1999, but in 2024, it's just an eyesore. And don't even get me started on the character animations‚Äîthey're about as fluid as a rock. üé®ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

> So, what's the deal with all the hype, you ask? Beats me. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

> Don't get me wrong, there are *some* redeeming qualities. Playing with friends can lead to a few chuckles and scares, and there's a certain charm to the chaos. But let's face it: novelty wears off faster than Bob trying to climb a ladder. üòë

> Within hours, I felt like I'd seen it all. One guy plays lookout while the rest scavenge, praying we don't become monster bait. Tension fades faster than a summer tan, and the graphics? Let's just say they're less "artistic choice" and more "lazy Sunday afternoon." üòëüé®

> With lobbies breaking left and right, modded chaos, and cheaters running amok, it's like playing Russian roulette with your sanity. üé≤ü§Ø

> And don't even get me started on the wasted potential. This game could've been a diamond in the rough, but instead, it's a lump of coal in the gaming world's stocking. üéÆüëé

> So, unless you enjoy frustration served with a side of disappointment, save your cash for something with a bit more substance. Trust me, your sanity will thank you. üôè

> TL;DR: Lethal Company is like a bad blind date‚Äîpromises excitement, delivers disappointment. [/b]

[b]  Title: Lethal Company with the Addams Family

[The scene opens with the Addams Family gathered in their dimly lit living room. Gomez, Morticia, Wednesday, Pugsley, Uncle Fester, and Lurch are all present.]

Gomez: My dear family, tonight we embark on a thrilling adventure into the digital unknown!

Morticia: How delightful. Another opportunity to explore the darker corners of existence.

Wednesday: I can hardly contain my excitement. Finally, a game that matches the darkness of my soul.

Pugsley: I hope there are monsters. Lots of monsters!

Uncle Fester: And explosions! Lots of explosions!

Gomez: Fear not, my dear family. Lethal Company promises all that and more. Now, let us dive into the depths of the digital abyss!

[They gather around a glowing screen as Gomez presses play.]

Gomez: Ah, the eerie ambiance, the faint sounds of terror. It's positively enchanting!

Morticia: [with a smirk] Just like home.

Wednesday: Look at all the abandoned moons we can explore. How quaint.

Pugsley: I can't wait to encounter the monsters. They'll make excellent new friends.

Uncle Fester: And explosions! Did I mention explosions?

Lurch: [grunts in agreement]

[As they delve deeper into the game, they encounter scrap, traps, and monsters.]

Gomez: Ah, scrap! The currency of the peculiar. Let us gather as much as we can.

Morticia: [spotting a trap] How charming. A trap. How thoughtful of them to leave us such surprises.

Wednesday: [encountering a monster] Mother, father, we have visitors.

Pugsley: [excitedly] Can we keep it?

Uncle Fester: [brandishing a weapon] Time for some monster-bashing!

Lurch: [cracks his knuckles in preparation]

[They navigate through the game, facing challenges and overcoming obstacles with their unique Addams Family flair.]

Gomez: What an exhilarating adventure! I feel more alive than ever!

Morticia: Indeed, my dear. It's not every day we get to dance with danger.

Wednesday: I must say, the monsters were quite hospitable. Perhaps we should invite them for tea.

Pugsley: I've never had so much fun blowing things up!

Uncle Fester: [laughing maniacally] I feel like a child again! A very dangerous child.

Lurch: [nods approvingly]

[As they continue playing, the eerie glow of the screen casts shadows across the room, enveloping the Addams Family in a world of darkness and delight.]

Gomez: Ah, Lethal Company. A game truly befitting the Addams Family.

Morticia: Indeed, my love. A perfect blend of horror and humor.

Wednesday: Can we play again tomorrow?

Pugsley: I want to see more explosions!

Uncle Fester: I'm ready for round two!

Lurch: [grins in agreement]

[With laughter echoing through the mansion, the Addams Family continues their adventure into the unknown, embracing the darkness with open arms.]

[The scene fades to black as the sounds of their gameplay fill the air.] [/b]

[i] In the dark expanse of digital space, a game was born,
Lethal Company, they called it, with its shadows and its thorn.
Oh, Lethal Company, you promised thrills and frights,
But beneath your surface, we found sleepless nights.

Your moons were but a labyrinth, a repetitive domain,
With every turn, the same old traps, the same old monstrous bane.
We wandered through your corridors, our hopes held high,
But soon we found our patience wane, as excitement turned awry.

For in your realm, dear Company, boredom reigned supreme,
As we roamed your halls endlessly, like a never-ending dream.
Your monsters, once a terror, soon lost their ghastly might,
Reduced to mere annoyances, fading from our sight.

And as we faced each quota, a burden hard to bear,
We realized, with heavy hearts, you offered us despair.
But still, amidst our grievances, we tried to find delight,
Yet Lethal Company, you eluded us, lost in endless night.

For all your promises of fun, of terror, and of glee,
We found ourselves adrift, alone, in your vast, indifferent sea.
For in the end, it's clear to see, the truth we cannot hide,
Lethal Company, you broke us, in the shadows where we bide. [/i]

I would like to suggest some rework on stormy maps.

Knowing that I spend quite some time on stormy maps, I noticed that you can be safe by hiding a little time under things like infrastructures, boulders, pumpkins and trees.

I would still suggest to have better visuals or auditory clues to tell wheter you are safe or not : I think it will encourage more casuals players to tackle stormy maps in the end.

It's Lethal Company. I love it, you love it, we ALL love it!

1. Low amount of content. Only a few planet exteriors, a few interior rooms as well, joined together randomly. Stuff starts repeating real quick. 
2. Boring gameplay loop. You land, go in, grab stuff until you see the monster, then run away and bring stuff to the ship. There's no real challenge, mostly just luck. Either you quickly die or make it out. Alternatively, you can try killing monster with shovels, which exposes how bad fighting gameplay is (which is fine I guess, since you're not really meant to do that). 
3. Lack of global progression. Your quota increases until you fail to fulfil it, after that your save is wiped and you start everything from scratch. The only thing to play for is setting new quota records, if you don't care about records there's nothing to play for, what's the point if you lose everything anyway.

I am thoroughly enjoying this game, great mechanics and gameplay. The randomly spawning factory and mansion settings ensures that you rarely play the same maps multiple times in a row, providing a different experience each time. It would be nice to have the ability to inverse teleport to plays if they are selected on the monitor, however that is a personal preference.

Discovering the sight and sound mechanics of different mobs is interesting, and you are able to kill a majority of mobs through various means. Some are some that cannot be killed, but it would be nice to discover items in the building that can kill them, or at least temporarily trap or halt them (such as the coil-heads, ghost girl, and worms). 

The spawn rates of mines and turrets is also pretty decent, scuffed at some times with ridiculous high spawns, but is well balanced most of the time. Only downside is land mines spawning in entryways (inside main and fire exits), meaning you die the moment you enter and cannot proceed with game play. It would be cool to unlock or purchase an items which permanently destroys turrets, especially for high turret spawns. 

Different moons and their geographical environments and structures are well though out, are interesting to traverse and impact the game-play in a realistic way. The different weather events affecting the environments, such as rain creating quicksand, is a greatly constructed mechanic. It would be nice to get some new moons to explore in future updates, alongside additional internal layout (current ones are factory and mansion). 

Overall: I highly recommend this game as the game-play and mechanics are well thought through. I have met some great people through this game and believe other would enjoy this.

Though the game seems fun, there is a stability issue where I cannot play the game for more than 5-10 minutes before it freezes my entire PC.

I've tested my CPU, GPU, and RAM recently and I am running a pretty fresh installation of windows on above recommended specs. I can run any other game and any amount of software on my computer without any problems, so it's definitely the game itself.

I understand the game comes from a small developer, so I am open to suggestions for getting the game to run stable and would update my review if that can be achieved; that being said I cannot recommend purchasing a game that currently doesn't work for me.

Lethal Company is an outstanding multiplayer slapstick comedy game disguised as a survival horror, and there is very little I can say that has not already been said. Even my friends playing on years-old laptops with no discrete GPU can play this game with very few hitches due to its visual style, which is my personal favourite part of Lethal Company.

If you have an Nvidia GPU, I'd recommend turning on Shadowplay and set up the instant replay highlights on a hotkey. This game is a GIF generator in the best possible way, and I've caught my friends dying in the funniest possible ways more times than I can count.

My only complaint isn't even directly related to the game - the most popular mod manager is called Thunderstore, and it's laggy and terrible, forcibly bundled with Overwolf - yet another bloated overlay I need to turn off and disable on startup. I hope that Zeekerss - the sole developer responsible for Lethal Company - eventually adds Steam Workshop support, perhaps later in Early Access.

For ¬£8.50, this game is an absolute steal. If you've got a few friends and a spare evening, pick this one up and have a blast. It's worth the hype.

Potential Spoilers! Only read if you are okay with that!So far, at the time I'm writing this, I only have 3.6 hours. But I wanna say a few things about lethal company...
It's fun, first off. I like turning the lights off at night, and having a horror-comedy gameplay session with friends. The proximity chat makes the game SO MUCH BETTER in my opinion. When you're far, you're lonely, and you can plot things to betray your friends, and it can be really funny. Mixed with that is horror, monsters, and dark rooms, and mixed with both of those is a goal to meet a quota by getting loot and bringing it to a ship. I am excited to get more hours in this game, as it really scratches the itch of a great time with friends, bringing comedy, betrayal, horror, and more.

Lethal Company isn't just a game; it's a heart-pounding rollercoaster of hilarity and horror that will leave you on the edge of your seat, begging for more. With its ingenious fusion of comedy and adventure-horror genres, Lethal Company delivers an unparalleled gaming experience that transcends boundaries. From the moment you step into its twisted world, you're greeted with gut-busting humor that keeps you laughing uncontrollably, even as you navigate through spine-chilling scenarios that send shivers down your spine. The game's immersive storytelling and captivating characters draw you in like a moth to a flame, ensuring that every moment is filled with excitement and anticipation. With its impeccable blend of wit, suspense, and sheer terror, Lethal Company isn't just a game‚Äîit's a masterpiece that sets the bar for gaming excellence. Strap in, hold onto your funny bone, and prepare to embark on the adventure of a lifetime.

Amazing game, easy to learn - hard to master.
A ton of fun with friends, get your clipping-software ready because of the amount of hilarious stuff happening all the time. 
You should also consider installing some mods for extra fun & better experience.

Here's a list of some of my favorite mods!
- ReservedItemSlotCore & ReservedFlashlightSlot by Flipmods; Grants you an extra slot for your flashlight and also makes you able to turn them on by pressing F, even when holding something else
- TooManyEmotes by Flipmods; Adds over 200 Emotes
- NeedyCats by Jordo; Adds Cats that you can pick up and take with you! You can also sell them, but don't even think about that ,_,
- Skinwalkers by RugbugRedfern; One of the best & funniest mods yet also one of the scariest. With this mod, the monsters can mimic the voices of your team
- ALL_MY_FELLAS by ALLMYFELLAS; Makes the hoarding bugs play the song when they attack you
- YippeeMod by sunnobunno; The cutest mod! Makes you fall in love with hoarding bugs

A fantastic, fun game to play with your friends. I don't have anything bad to say to about the game, except for a few bugs, but even those often just result in hilarious mayhem that this game aims to be.

Difference being, though, that you are the subject of that mayhem. Prepare to die a lot, prepare to get bullshitted.

The atmosphere is very stressful, as the game registers your microphone and most of the enemies act based on sound, which limits your communication using the in-game voice chat only. Don't you dare to cheat using Discord, you will lose the majority of the experience the game offers with it's narrow, dark hallways, where you might either find the salvation from getting fired by the corporation, or a scary creature you can't tell your friends about so it doesn't hear you.

5/5 highly recommended!

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

A really simple and easy to understand game that is truly very engaging! Truly it has been mine and my friends' means to hang out during our busy schedules in which it's jut been so much fun. I haven't had such a great multiplayer experience since the early days of Phasmophobia so this was incredibly refreshing. 

Alongside the easy to understand game play the budding lore is honestly really interesting to get into??  The logs that can be found around the map are an interesting read and show how much love goes into this game. 

The monsters-- the MONSTERS are so incredibly cool even just design alone but also how they all function. Learning the quirks of each monster has been such a fun part of the game even if it can be frustrating when I make a personal slip up of not checking behind my back for the Bracken every ten seconds/j. Also the Jester is such a great concept for a monster. Seeing it to the eventual cranking makes even a repeat of the Jester such a nerve-wracking experience because of how just *final* it feels to have the Jester on your tail. Nothing beats the first time Jester experience of having a box on legs trying to harass you lmao

All in all: this game is great. Great fun, great accessibility level for non-gamers, great starting lore, great monsters and scares!

I didn't expect this to be a game that I'd play for a long time but I was hoping for more than a couple of hours.  It's a simple premise and it sounds like it's going to be fun but when you scratch the surface away it's not for lots of reasons:

Visibility is awful.  I don't mean the facilities are dark, that's to be expected but everything is foggy, mushy and washed out.  You can't read text on the screens unless you press your face into them, half the time your torch just reflects off the fog in front of you and makes it harder to see down a dark corridor.  It just feels like I'm running around with grease in my eyes constantly.

The interface is very clumsy.  I get the point that doors should take time to open so monsters can grab you etc. but having four hotbar/carry slots and not being able to select items with a key, the only way being to use the mouse wheel which you can't invert and for me it cycles the wrong way (won't bother everyone).  Add in the visibility issue which affects the UI as well and swapping to your utility items is really frustrating.  Not in a challenging way but in a way that feels like it was done as a cheap way to add challenge.

Nothing is explained.  Again, maybe that's supposed to be part of the charm but it just feels cheap/lazy.  How do we use the terminal to open doors?  How do we sell items?  I could go on but almost nothing is explained and it doesn't feel fun to discover it just frustrating that it's not explained and not intuitive.

Communication is a problem.  We played "fair" and didn't use Discord while in mission but after finally working out that you can buy walkie talkies and the ship doesn't have a built in communicator you won't have enough cash to buy one for everyone and people not holding one can't hear voices from them very well.  Having someone talk three rooms away drowns out the voice from the teammate monitoring you from the ship who is probably telling you something important.  It's really hard to tell where sounds are coming from or how close things are.

Four of us played this and we're used to communicating on games but this just felt hard work in a tedious way.  I'm sure you can learn the monster patterns and ways to counter them but we just avoided them with help from the poor sod who had to stay on the ship and practise his typing skills instead of having fun.  The increasing quotas again feels like a cheap way to force you to up the difficulty and ultimately die.  The monsters are good for a jump scare but there doesn't feel like any challenge, if you're not careful they surprise you and you die and if you are they never get close.  If it looked a little cleaner and played smoother we'd maybe forgive some of its faults and give it more of a chance but unfortunately I feel like we wouldn't have our minds changed that it is ultimately a very shallow experience.

# A Critical Perspective on the Gaming Experience
I purchased the game influenced by the trend, but the current experience falls short of satisfaction. The endless gameplay mechanics and the inevitability of death create an uncomfortable feeling. The sudden reset after spending time strategizing with four players is unpleasant. I suggest that additional items, decorations, and clothing become permanent, persisting even after death. This could maintain interest and motivate continued play.
The game poses the paradox of gaining much but, in the end, being abandoned by capitalists. This touch of black humor gives it a distinctive flavor, and despite the criticisms, I give it a positive evaluation.

With how this game thrived this year, it is simply fun to play. Let it be solo gameplay, public meetups with randoms, or with friends, the game is fun but not too addicting. Hearing laughs in the background dying ain't so bad compared to the jumpscares you will experience in this game. 99% guarantee your money is well-spent on this game, unless you just absolutely hate scary stuff or don't want the solo experience. I mean, there is a public server full of lobbies. You don't really have to be playing alone unless you want to. Not to mention, the game can be modded to either play with more friends or strangers, or simply spice the game up with mods that range from quality of life experience to brutally fun extra contents that becomes a fun-ny experience. At this point, I love the game. Not deeply into its story or content, but meeting wholesome people who may become your friends in the future is really fun

From the outset, "Lethal Company" ensnares the player's psyche in a labyrinthine narrative, weaving a tapestry that juxtaposes the macabre and the mirthful with such deftness that one might find themselves oscillating between shrieks of terror and paroxysms of laughter within a singular, breathless moment. The game's premise‚Äîa conclave of eccentrics summoned to a seemingly derelict mansion under the guise of an innocuous invitation, only to find themselves ensnared in a spectral prankster's eldritch game of survival‚Äîserves as the fertile loam from which springs forth an experience unparalleled in its capacity to entertain and horrify.

A very shallow cash grab made popular through canny twitch and you tube advertising and appealing to children and idiots - like me. I wish I'd figured it out .9 of an hour earlier so I could refund it. 

The graphics are hideous, not even charmingly so, they just suck, visibility is non-existent to hide the god awful animation and models. Entity behaviour is entirely random and counter-less, or so obscure you basically wander around in the dark until you are murdered, after which there's nothing to do. It's funny listening to your friends try and contact you... the first time, after that you end up spinning up Netflix or something because your bored, at which point you have to ask yourself, is this a good use of time?

We basically figured out how to beat the game reliably within a couple of hours, anyone with a reasonably good set of explorers and somebody good on the terminal and you just avoid the red dots, stick to the safe spots. Since there's no method to "out play" the entities there is simply no point engaging with them.

As I write this review DOOM 2016 is on sale for ¬£3.99, LESS THAN THIS HEAP of rubbish. You'll boot DOOM up and be amazed at the fluidity of the graphics and refinement of the genre... or you could cry yourself to sleep and buy this instead.

Some great ideas cobbled together poorly into a Unity game. 

I can certainly see why its popular with the brainless masses on Twitch because watching some thicc emo thot's cleavage bouncing away in a hot tub while they play Lethal Company, combined with; [i]funny jump-scares! Arrgh a spider! It's dark, whats that noise?! tee-hee, watch me play and get scared with me wuwu[/i] actually sounds pretty entertaining, for a few minutes at least.

However playing it myself and with friends, sadly the gameplay loop of entering a building, collecting scrap, surviving / meeting quota gets dry after the second loop when you realise that this is all there is. I saw everything I was going to see within a couple of hours - so if you're curious, or just want those Twitch bait clips you can probably get them and refund this back in time.

I hope things are added to Lethal Company that lure me back, updates, workshop etc - but for now, this will be collecting dust somewhere in the depths of my Steam library.

Lethal company is an excellent team-based horror game occasionally marred by clout-chasers, tyrannical hosts, and irritating children. You can't change that, so my recommendation is to host a game or play with your friends (I recommend muting your Discord once the ship lands). Though I will say, there are nice and chill players here, you just need to search beyond the reprobates, cringe-lords, beta-male orbiters, femcels, and streamers. They have their own agendas and ulterior motives, so I can guarantee that if things turn sour, you'll get the boot. Avoid it, find cool players, just be polite, give them a few chances, and you'll have a hey-day. This is not a popularity contest, and the jester is not funny when he/she is taking a flying dump on other players, so I'd avoid being an obstacle as there are already enough of them that you'll need to overcome as a team.

Let me preface this by saying that The Upturned was one of my favourite games last year, and it placed Zeekerss high-up on my radar. They get horror, they get comedy, they get world-building, and they get writing. In Lethal Company, this one contains a similar flourish, though the horror is more self-serious and enunciated than the comedy is in The Upturned. There are funny moments primarily fuelled by player dialogue and ambient occurrences, but the world is bleak, unknowable, oppressive, and indelibly cruel.

It's accessible, but higher difficulties will give you a run for your money. The game-play systems are quite bare-bones, but the nuances of the game creep in latently, and there's a lot of secret little strategies, contextual details, and patterns that you will acquire piecemeal, learnt in time with a little bit of curiosity and experimentation. They enhance your understanding of the game-world as you acquire them and familiarity becomes your greatest weapon, far more so than a shotgun (though the shotgun is quite good, keep the safety on at all times). Also skips and exploits are possible but it's up to the developer whether such things should be preserved.

In terms of loop, it's minimalistic, but there's a lot of jelly in these doughnuts. This game does a great job at utilising a reductive approach, you're more or less naked aside from your jumpsuit, and the few tools you do have are mostly weak but balanced. They all come with compromise. You can't hoard items. You each have four inventory slots, and as a team you need to plan efficiently as the quota increases. You collect scrap, and deliver it to your employer, The Company. You are dogged by the fauna and weather of the moons (planets more accurately), and when I say fauna, I mean awful monstrous creatures, cryptid-likes, and nightmarish entities beyond accurate description. You loop back over and over again until the quota is unreachable. Missing the quota within the allotted time enacts the disciplinary process. You don't want that. But it will happen eventually.

There is next to no soundtrack. I loved The Upturned soundtrack, but for Lethal Company it works. Some more atmospheric textures and musical embellishments wouldn't be out of place, but sparse is a fitting approach. As a whole, Lethal Company is stark, isolating, barren, and sterile. Your colleagues are your only light in the darkness (unless you have a pro-flashlight). The world feels undead, it seems to want you to die, the creatures help that fact, and even your employer may dispense you.

I'm interested to see where this thing goes, because as far as the core experience is concerned, Zeekerss has nailed it so far, creating a unique horror in a world that I am curious about.

A fun old game overall. 8/10 so far, not as good as The Upturned in my opinion, but it's only a matter of time before I can officially classify that. I want more subtle allusions to the world and more lore-based tidbits to discover while I am playing this game, because as a whole the central experience and minute-to-minute game-play is already optimal thus far.

Sections that mix-up the format and focus on obstacles other than scavenging would be welcome as well, a crash-landing? Space-stations? Isolated combat scenarios? Marooning? Lost cargo? Debris fields? Inside the company? Links to Upturned? The last one is asking too much I know. A little twist of the unexpected goes a long way, but there's plenty of that already. Randomisation and diversions go hand in hand with the uncertainty of it all. To go off the beaten path against your better judgement.

This game is brilliant. It's spooky and can make you uncomfortable but it leaves room for some fun among friends. The proximity voice chat is fantastic and this game seems to have the best comedic timing. Playing with randoms isn't too bad either, made a few friends joining random lobbies. 

Mods are supported and can add so much to the game. 
Game too hard? Download some stamina/upgradable stat mods. 
Game too easy? Download some new enemies and/or locations.  
Even after playing with mods, I went back to play vanilla Lethal and it's still fun. Huge recommend.

Introduction
Lethal Company is a game that masterfully blends elements from various genres, creating a unique and thrilling experience. In this essay, we‚Äôll delve into the reasons why this indie title has garnered attention and why it‚Äôs worth your time.

The Premise
Imagine exploring abandoned lunar tunnels with your closest friends, clad in hazmat suits, scavenging for loot. The catch? The tunnels are haunted, and grotesque, white-eyed monsters lurk around every corner. Your goal: gather valuable resources and safely transport them back to your ship. Welcome to Lethal Company.

The Riveting Loop
The heart of Lethal Company lies in its gameplay loop. Each successful run allows your squad to invest in better gear, from flashlights to high-powered jetpacks. The limited inventory space adds tension‚Äîyou must choose wisely between essential items like flashlights and walkie-talkies. These tools are crucial for survival but can be challenging to recover if things go awry deep within a dungeon.

Challenges and Cosmic Horrors
The game throws a plethora of challenges and secret dangers at you. Hidden turrets, cosmic horrors, and unexpected twists keep players on their toes. Even in death, the experience remains entertaining. Watching surviving teammates outrun danger or scream while hauling a piece of scrap adds comic relief. The death cam captures these moments, making each playthrough memorable.

Sound Design and Wonder
Lethal Company excels in sound design. The eerie noises, mysterious areas, and frozen moons create genuine horror. It‚Äôs not about cheap jumpscares or mindless gore; it‚Äôs about the atmosphere‚Äîthe feeling of being on the edge of discovery.

Multiplayer Magic
The game truly shines in multiplayer mode. Playing with friends enhances the experience. Whether you‚Äôre strategizing, laughing, or screaming together, the camaraderie elevates the gameplay. If you have a group of friends who enjoy multiplayer games, Lethal Company is tailor-made for you.

The Work-in-Progress Aspect
Despite its strengths, Lethal Company remains a work in progress. The graphics can be janky, and the lack of a robust story might leave some players wanting more. However, the potential for growth and discovery keeps players engaged.

Conclusion
In summary, Lethal Company offers an incredible multiplayer experience. Its low price point makes it accessible, and the thrill of exploration, combined with the camaraderie of friends, ensures that you‚Äôll lose yourself in its haunting depths. So grab your hazmat suit, assemble your team, and venture forth‚Äîthere‚Äôs plenty left to discover on the frozen moon of Rend123.

Remember, sometimes the scariest things aren‚Äôt the monsters in the dark, but the secrets waiting to be unearthed. Happy scavenging!

Introduction:
Lethal Company is an ambitious addition to the world of tactical shooters, offering a blend of intense action and strategic gameplay. Developed by an indie studio, it seeks to carve its niche in a genre dominated by giants. This review aims to provide a balanced assessment of its strengths and weaknesses.

Graphics and Audio (4/5):
Visually, Lethal Company delivers a solid experience. The environments are richly detailed, from urban landscapes to dense forests, creating immersive battlegrounds. Character models are well-designed, though lacking some variety. The game's sound design is commendable, with realistic weapon sounds adding to the immersion. However, occasional glitches and optimization issues detract from an otherwise polished presentation.

Gameplay (3.5/5):
At its core, Lethal Company offers a satisfying tactical experience. Players are tasked with completing missions ranging from hostage rescue to sabotage, requiring careful planning and coordination. The game's cover system and variety of weapons provide tactical depth, encouraging strategic thinking over brute force. However, AI behavior can be inconsistent, with enemies sometimes exhibiting unnatural reactions or patterns. Additionally, the lack of a robust tutorial can leave newcomers feeling overwhelmed, impacting accessibility.

Story and Characters (3/5):
While Lethal Company attempts to weave a compelling narrative, it falls short of its aspirations. The plot revolves around a private military corporation embroiled in global conflicts, yet the storytelling feels formulaic and fails to fully engage players. Characters lack depth, often feeling like archetypal soldiers rather than fleshed-out individuals. Despite occasional moments of intrigue, the narrative struggles to leave a lasting impact.

Multiplayer (4/5):
Lethal Company shines brightest in its multiplayer component, offering intense competitive matches and cooperative missions. The diverse maps and modes cater to various playstyles, ensuring replayability. Cooperative missions are particularly enjoyable, fostering camaraderie as players work together to overcome challenges. However, occasional server issues and matchmaking imbalances can hinder the overall experience.

Replay Value (3.5/5):
While Lethal Company offers a decent amount of content, its replay value is somewhat limited. The campaign, while enjoyable, lacks branching paths or meaningful choices that incentivize multiple playthroughs. Similarly, the multiplayer, while engaging, may struggle to retain players in the long run without regular updates or additional content.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Lethal Company presents a mixed bag of exhilarating moments and missed opportunities. While its solid gameplay mechanics and multiplayer offerings provide moments of excitement, shortcomings in storytelling, AI behavior, and replay value prevent it from reaching its full potential. Nevertheless, for fans of tactical shooters seeking a new challenge, Lethal Company offers an experience worth diving into, albeit with tempered expectations.

A true indie game and the first game I can say for while is FUN! Graphics are hit and miss for some people however I feel the lack of HD and 4K modern style give this game a simple quirkiness that is lovable, it adds to the simplicity and goofiness for me, I also like that it makes the game accessible for all as you do not need a powerful computer to play it. 
The sound on this game on the other hand is absolutely out of this world! I would highly recommend game chat as it adds so  much to the experience.

It's early access so yes there are some bugs, but don't let this put you off trying the game they are not game breaking.

Skill level is a non-issue in this game also as you are destined to eventually fail and be ejected into the depths of space. 

The mod support for the game is fantastic which I think will be what keeps the game fresh as vanilla can get a little tiring after a while. 

I really hope the dev team keep the casual feel to the game with further updates, and I am for once excited to see what the next update holds in a game.

Lethal Company is currently the best co-op horror game on the market even in it's early access! It's very affordable and it's guaranteed that you will have a ton of fun (with friends). The graphics are really simple and have a slight touch of some toon shaders that just fit perfectly into the artstyle. It will 100% run on your grandma's computer without a struggle. There is some optimization issues though, but that will definitely get fixed in future updates. The gameplay loop is really simple - you and your team land on various abandoned moons ranging from a pretty safe industrialized desert moon to a very dangerous frozen, rocky moon with lots of unknown entities waiting in the depths of dark hallways for the perfect moment to strike. Your task is to explore said moons and collect leftover scrap to meet your 3-day profit quota. When the deadline finally arrives, you need to immediately sell your stuff at "The Company Building". The profit quota increases and then the cycle repeats. What does happen when you don't meet the quota? Well... let's just say you get promptly "fired" from "The Company" and you have to start over. This game is great with friends but if you're a person who prefers the solo experience, you're gonna have a bad time. The game is awfully hard while playing alone. The RNG might sometimes kill you just because it feels like it and you're going to lose all of your collected scrap. I do not recommend playing Lethal Company solo as it is just straight bullshit. If you're fine with losing your progress over and over again then be my guest but it's not worth it. There is one amazing thing with playing solo though. The game becomes... awfully quiet. There's something about the atmosphere when you're alone that's just frightening. It builds tension really well and you're always on your toes. It leaves you with a feeling that a monster could jump out of every corner. Still wouldn't recommend it. Just get some friends with you and you will have so much more fun! Overall this game is awesome. Even though it's still in early access while writing this review, it still feels like a finished product. Definitely would recommend this game for some late night games with friends! It's worth your money.

Lethal Company is a gripping addition to the tactical shooter genre, developed by a talented indie team that goes by the name "Vanguard Games." Released amidst a sea of competitors, Lethal Company manages to stand out with its blend of intense action, strategic depth, and a compelling storyline that keeps players on the edge of their seats from start to finish.

Gameplay: 9/10

At its core, Lethal Company offers a highly satisfying tactical shooting experience. Players are thrust into the role of an elite operative tasked with taking down a shadowy organization bent on global domination. The gameplay seamlessly blends fast-paced action with strategic decision-making. Each mission presents a variety of objectives, from stealthy infiltration to all-out assaults, allowing players to tackle challenges in multiple ways.

The game's weapon customization system is a standout feature, offering an impressive array of options to fine-tune firearms to suit individual playstyles. Whether you prefer silenced pistols for covert operations or heavy machine guns for frontal assaults, Lethal Company has you covered.

Graphics and Sound: 8/10

Visually, Lethal Company impresses with its detailed environments, realistic character models, and stunning special effects. From urban landscapes to dense jungles, each location feels distinct and immersive. The sound design further enhances the experience, with dynamic audio cues adding to the tension during intense firefights.

Storyline: 8/10

While not groundbreaking, Lethal Company's storyline serves its purpose well, providing a compelling backdrop for the action-packed gameplay. The plot unfolds through a series of well-crafted cutscenes and in-game dialogue, keeping players engaged as they uncover the sinister motives of the game's antagonists.

Replay Value: 7/10

With multiple difficulty settings, hidden collectibles, and a robust online multiplayer mode, Lethal Company offers plenty of reasons to revisit its adrenaline-fueled world. However, the relatively short campaign may leave some players craving more content in the long run.

Overall: 8/10

Lethal Company delivers a thrilling tactical shooter experience that will satisfy fans of the genre. With its blend of intense action, strategic depth, and captivating storyline, it's a must-play for anyone looking for their next adrenaline rush. Whether you're a lone wolf operative or prefer team-based multiplayer battles, Lethal Company has something for everyone.

One of the best co-op experiences released in a while, 'Lethal Company' boasts a very simple premise: join the mysterious company and scavenge scrap in the abandoned facilities on a variety of moons to meet the constantly increasing quota. Each moon has its own fauna and dangers, which for the most part are static and an abandoned facility, usually with multiple entrances, which is generated based on a random seed, keeping the game fresh and exciting.

While you can venture on your journey alone and try your luck with the unpredictably brutal worlds, where the game truly excels is in co-op play. You can join with either your friends or public lobbies of up to four people. The game actively rewards planning and communication. Even staying behind on the ship, while the rest of the party explores the facilities, is a viable approach. One of the most crucial tools provided by the company is the terminal and monitoring systems on the ship, allowing for one player to observe party members who are alive, guide them to significant pathways for more scrap or an exit, inform them about lurking dangers, open blast doors, and disable turrets.

Though the facilities may seem calm at first, they look undoubtedly eerie. With limited resources, venturing deep into each maze to reach that last piece of scrap for the quota may sometimes seem necessary, but you may soon find yourself lost, panicking, and unable to find your way back. But more importantly, you are never truly alone in the facilities; something far more dangerous than a few turrets lurks in the darkness. Some creatures might not be particularly dangerous unless disturbed, but others will actively seek you out and prevent you from ever leaving.

Graphically, the game may not look stunning, but it doesn't have to be. The subliminal spaces that the game employs, along with simplistic graphics and an intense focus on the details and dangers of the world, are what keep you on the edge of your seat.

The sound design is absolutely phenomenal and heavily works to the game's advantage, especially in the closed spaces within the facility. The echoing sound of footsteps approaching or hearing voices from afar fuels the feeling of dread and excitement.

Overall, the game is not perfect, far from it. There are numerous bugs that may seem unfair. But the company never claimed that anything is going to be fair; the odds were always stacked against you. Eventually, you will lose, you will fail to meet that quota, and when you do, there will be someone else to replace you.

"Embarking on a journey into the heart of "Lethal Company" is akin to stepping into a meticulously crafted world where strategy reigns supreme and every decision carries profound consequences. Developed by a team of visionary creators, this game stands as a beacon of excellence in the realm of interactive entertainment, seamlessly blending tactical depth with adrenaline-fueled action. As an ardent admirer of the gaming landscape, I am compelled to delve deeper into the myriad facets of this captivating masterpiece.
     At the nexus of "Lethal Company" lies its masterfully crafted gameplay, a symphony of strategic intricacy and pulse-pounding excitement. Players assume the mantle of tactical commanders, entrusted with the leadership of elite squads navigating treacherous missions across a dystopian landscape. Each decision, whether it be resource allocation, squad composition, or battlefield tactics, resonates with tangible consequences, fostering a sense of agency and immersion unparalleled in contemporary gaming. Whether orchestrating covert operations under the cloak of darkness or engaging in blistering firefights amidst the chaos of urban warfare, the gameplay remains consistently engaging and dynamically challenging.
     The visual and auditory tapestry woven within "Lethal Company" is nothing short of breathtaking, setting a new standard for aesthetic excellence in gaming. From the sweeping vistas of war-torn landscapes to the intricate details adorning characters and weaponry, every facet of the game's visual design is a testament to the dedication and craftsmanship of its developers. The evocative sound design further enhances the immersive experience, from the thunderous roar of gunfire to the subtle ambient noises that imbue each environment with a sense of life and authenticity. Together, these elements coalesce to create an audiovisual experience that transcends mere entertainment, enveloping players in a world teeming with depth and vibrancy.
     Beneath the surface of "Lethal Company" lies a narrative tapestry as rich and compelling as any found in the annals of literature or cinema. Set against the backdrop of a near-future dystopia rife with political intrigue and moral ambiguity, the game's storyline unfolds with all the nuance and complexity of a finely woven tapestry. As players navigate the machinations of rival factions and grapple with the consequences of their choices, they are drawn deeper into a world where alliances are forged and broken, and the line between friend and foe becomes increasingly blurred. The characters, each imbued with their own motivations and desires, leap off the screen with a sense of authenticity and depth seldom seen in gaming, making every interaction and decision feel both meaningful and consequential.
     One of the most remarkable aspects of "Lethal Company" is its unparalleled replay value, offering players a veritable cornucopia of strategic possibilities and narrative permutations to explore. Whether charting new tactical approaches, delving into alternate storylines, or testing their mettle in multiplayer skirmishes, the game offers endless avenues for discovery and experimentation. Each playthrough unveils new layers of depth and complexity, ensuring that no two experiences are ever quite the same. For those who crave challenge and variety, "Lethal Company" stands as an inexhaustible wellspring of excitement and intrigue, beckoning players to return time and time again to uncover its many secrets.
     In conclusion, "Lethal Company" stands as a triumph of the human imagination, a testament to the boundless creativity and ingenuity of its developers. With its impeccable gameplay mechanics, stunning visuals, gripping narrative, and infinite replayability, it transcends the confines of traditional gaming to become a bona fide work of art. For both seasoned strategists and casual gamers alike, "Lethal Company" offers an unforgettable journey into the heart of interactive entertainment, inviting players to immerse themselves in a world teeming with danger, intrigue, and limitless possibility."

   - Albert Einstein, probably

I am a father of two, and I have a hard time connecting with my oldest son. My son is a gamer, and I bought him his first console when he was 7. I thought I was doing him good, as he enjoyed it, but our relationship has been growing further and further apart. I began thinking of ways to connect with my son again, and I recently downloaded steam on my personal laptop. After logging into my sons steam account and checking out the games he played, I noticed that he has been playing this recently. So I bought it for myself, and asked my son if I could play with him. He said I could and I have been enjoying playing this with my son. I have also gotten several games that my son has been playing, and enjoying them with him as well. This game has repaired me and my sons relationship. I thank the developer for making this game and allowing me to reconnect with my son.

I really love almost everything about this game. The community is fun, the monsters can be horrifying, and the game is essentially a tight-knit ball of chaos. I remember when we decided to make another run on Vow. We eventually got trapped, as there were Coil-Heads on both sides. I love how this game also has a risk-reward system. Do you stay in the ship and guide your teammates, or do you just run into the thick of it with only a shovel and a dream? Both can be very entertaining, and each with their own pros and cons. One issue I have had though is the servers, but whenever I get in a game, a good time is almost certain.

Lethal Company is the perfect game for people who love frustration and disappointment. It's like the developers set out to make the most infuriating game possible. The controls are clunky, the graphics are outdated, and the AI is so dumb it's almost comical. But hey, at least the loading screens are long enough to take a nap during. If you're looking for a game to make you question why you even bother playing video games, Lethal Company is the one for you.

I am not normally one to like horror games. They are one of my least favorite genres of games and I don't handle scary stuff well. However, Lethal Company broke through my shell and I ended up loving it, and it's not because it's not scary. One thing I appreciate is not having screamers. With games like FNAF, I never liked how the fear factor was just the fear of getting a loud jump scare. This game is genuinely terrifying without needing something to shout loudly into your ear periodically. On top of the scary aspect, the game also manages to be quite funny. I've met a lot of fun people on here and the game is still a blast to play 90 hours later. I don't think I've ever put this much time into a game as quickly as this one. I give it a 9/10. The only reason it is not a ten is because I think some things like the stamina could use a little tweaking to feel limiting but not too annoying.

The best co-operative game I've played in years. The most impressive thing is that even when you're terrible at it, it still manages to be fun, which means you can bring along people of all skill levels and they'll still have a great time. It's super fun to rack up huge quotas and keep the company happy, it's equally fun to get absolutely obliterated by a bad dice roll because a disastrous run is usually delivered with such swift brutality that it's hilarious.

The mod community for this game gives it more or less infinite replay value at the moment, which is just an added bonus, but even vanilla Lethal is outstanding. I've played 50 hours and probably watched 100+ hours more. 

The only thing I'd say is that it is absolutely at its most fun with groups of 4 people or more, so I hope that the player limit in the vanilla version is increased substantially (I'd say 8 or 10 as the default limit is ideal) before it goes to 1.0.

Ingredients:
1 box (14.1 oz) refrigerated Pillsbury‚Ñ¢ Pie Crusts (2 Count), softened as directed on the box
6 cups thinly sliced, peeled apples (6 medium)
3/4 cup sugar
2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1 tablespoon lemon juice
Instructions:
Heat the oven to 425¬∞F.
In a small bowl, combine sugar, flour, and spices.
Toss the sliced apples with lemon juice in a large bowl.
Add the sugar mixture to the apples and toss to coat.
Roll out the pie crust and place it in a pie dish.
Add the apple filling to the crust.
Dot the filling with butter.
Cover with the remaining pie crust and seal the edges.
Cut slits in the top crust for venting.
Bake for about 45-50 minutes until golden brown and bubbly.
Calories per serving: 560

Title: Dairy Delights: A Milk and Cheese Company Review

Introduction:
Dairy Delights, a purveyor of milk and cheese products, embodies the essence of dairy excellence. From creamy milk to artisanal cheeses, they offer a delectable array of dairy delights. In this review, we delve into the various aspects of Dairy Delights, exploring its flavors, quality, and customer experience.

Product Quality:
Dairy Delights prides itself on sourcing the finest ingredients for its milk and cheese products. Their milk is fresh, creamy, and brimming with wholesome goodness, sourced from local farms known for their superior dairy practices. Each cheese is meticulously crafted, reflecting the expertise and dedication of their skilled cheesemakers. From tangy cheddars to velvety bries, Dairy Delights' cheeses consistently impress with their rich flavors and impeccable textures.

Flavor Variety:
One of the standout features of Dairy Delights is its diverse range of flavors. Whether you prefer the subtle sweetness of a creamy milk or the bold tang of an aged cheese, there's something to suit every palate. Their flavored cheeses, such as garlic herb or jalapeno jack, add an exciting twist to traditional favorites, making each bite a flavorful adventure.

Sustainability and Ethical Practices:
Dairy Delights is committed to sustainable and ethical dairy production. They prioritize environmentally-friendly practices, minimizing their carbon footprint and promoting animal welfare. By supporting local farms and implementing eco-conscious initiatives, Dairy Delights demonstrates a commendable dedication to responsible dairy sourcing.

Customer Experience:
From the moment you step into Dairy Delights' charming storefront to the last bite of their delicious cheeses, the customer experience is nothing short of delightful. Knowledgeable staff members are always on hand to offer recommendations and share their passion for dairy. Whether you're a seasoned cheese connoisseur or a curious newcomer, Dairy Delights welcomes you with warmth and enthusiasm.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Dairy Delights stands as a paragon of milk and cheese excellence. With their commitment to quality, flavor variety, sustainability, and exceptional customer experience, they have earned their place as a beloved fixture in the world of dairy. Whether you're craving a glass of refreshing milk or a decadent cheese platter, Dairy Delights delivers nothing short of dairy perfection.

Lethal Company is one of the only games to utterly grip me in the last few years. The simplistic gameplay loop is not only designed to make you keep improving skills and pushing your high score, but also leads for boundless fun, especially with friends. This game is tailored to all types of players. The scavengers, the fighters, the explorers, and the people just looking for a casual good time - everyone can find something for them in Lethal Company.

I've always loved such media as the SCP-Foundation, so encountering monsters inspired by such was as much as a horror as it was a joy. Their designs are simplistic, goofy, and sometimes cute, but often terrifying upon first contact. Stumbling upon a new enemy, panicking and adapting to their abilities is all part of the fun.

The items in Lethal Company are what truly keep the game worth playing. They add an unpredictability and utility to the game that can make you feel remarkably stupid yet remarkably clever at the same time. Yes, I can spray my friends with fluorescent paint, but I can also mark my way back to the ship. Yes, I can squish my friends with ladders, but I can also reach places of the map not available to me before. Yes, I can blast music through my boombox and have a dance battle, but I can also lure enemies away with the audio.

Part of what I find so enjoyable about Lethal Company is the lack of information given to you. Often I find games will throw mountains of text at you, explaining every nook and cranny, every tech and tactic, and it can become exhausting and subjugating. Zeekers has done a wonderful job at allowing you to find information yourself in the world, particularly using your 'scan' ability. Finally understanding how a particular enemy or obstacle works, and learning how to combat it, is an amazing feeling, because you know that it was YOU who figured that out.

People may call the art style 'ugly' but I believe it to be genius. It's gritty, it's unsettling and its simplistic nature really lands itself home in my personal love for unique graphics. The world of Lethal Company is not somewhere you belong, and the aesthetics have reflected that perfectly.

The game runs very well on my sub-par laptop, mostly due to the low poly-count, and I have only ever encountered a few glitches (most which made the game funnier and all which fixed with a simple reset on the server). Mods are easy to run, and servers are easy to set up. This is an efficient game with endless enjoyment that I'm sure will keep us all entertained for years to come, and is WELL worth the price. 

Truly, Lethal Company is a game that proves simplism superior.

Thank you, Zeekers!

"At least we made quota, at least we made quota," I tell myself as I tremble on the floor of the ship's cargo hold. The blood of my fellow employees, my friends, drips from my hands. Their voices and screams still echo in my mind as the now red shovel stares at me from across the room. "For the Company," I say one final time before taking off to the stars, leaving the memories behind and the mission ahead.
YES

This game is teamwork-incarnate. I have never played a more team-based game than this one.
A combination of horror, comedy, and genuine pressure to do a good job makes them game more than just a treat; it's a full-course meal. Memorable designs, near-infinite replayability, and endless strategy with many ways to play. From scavenging the moon's facilities to staying back on the ship to help the team, there's a play style for every player.

Highly recommend this with friends, but if you don't have any; solo may prove a whole lot of fun as well! Just remember; you're a valuable asset to the company.

I recommend these mods; More company (essential, bigger lobbies + cosmetics.), Late company (Makes it so people can join when you go back to space, essential.), BadAssCompany (My favorite mod, basically just fotnites emote system plus features like duo emotes and stuff + music.) and YT boombox (fun, lets you play youtube links on the boombox.)

Absolutely amazing game with both the element of horror and comedy, specifically when playing with friends. I really enjoy having the thrill of not knowing which monster is going to come after me, although I personally think certain monsters should only appear on specific planets, in or out of the facility/mansion. This leads me on to my suggestion of definitely adding some more monsters/creatures. There is nothing I dislike about this game and I think it's a 10/10. Everyone should find the time to play this with friends if you want a bit of a laugh and a scare. Message to the producers of this game is that your game is a masterpiece which well deserves more recognition.

We were an expert and three newcomers (I was one of the newcomers) collecting scrap. Me and the expert stayed back at the ship while the other two newcomers went inside. The expert's instinct was to go and grab a beehive, dropped it in front of the ship's door, and then died to the bees. I died seconds prior to the same bees.

Meanwhile, the other two people inside got upset that the expert didn't grab a walkie-talkie (which he did), followed by them eagerly awaiting his death (again, which he did). Once they returned to the ship, they realized what happened, blaming me and my chaotic energy first and foremost.

We all ended up dying to the same bees. I have never laughed this hard before.

VERY GOOD game

I still am in disbelief that this is an indie game, and here are some reasons why.

First, the gameplay is beyond expected from a game like this. Being able to play it again and again with your friends over and over without having the same experience twice is a very rare find these days, especially in the indie game industry. Usually games like these get boring after a while, but I am still finding this game overwhelmingly fun.

Second, the voice chat mechanics are very innovative. An example is when you are being eaten by a snare flea (it's covering your head), your voice sounds muffled to others. Are you in a different room than your friend? Their voice is going to sound different when it comes through a wall. Even the proximity chat is amazing. I've NEVER seen voice chat like this in any game ever, and it's crazy to me that it comes from a fairly new indie dev.

Third, the gameplay mechanics overall are amazing. The main objective (collecting space trash from different moons to fulfill your ever-growing quota for the company) is so simple, yet depending on where you go it's always going to be a different experience. You can encounter monsters, hazardous weather, and even get lost in the facility that you entered. It has amazing replay ability (like I mentioned before) and is a very fun game to play with your friends.

All for the price of $10 or less. There is absolutely no better way to spend your money on Steam than on this game.

Lethal Company is one of the first games of it's own kind. It's graphics is unique and it's gameplay is even more unique. The horror aspect is perfect for a game like this, where you scavenge searching for junk, metal or even lollipops! Lethal Company has it's game solely based around taking risks, and what I mean by that is by searching deeper for junk is very rewarding but the 'entities' lurking nearby will not mess around. This game makes you prone to almost every sound in the game, as the game uses frequent sound queues or even music to hint towards some sort of creature, monster or entity (whatever you want to call it) as if you don't stay aware, a lanky man might just come from behind you and break your neck. Aswell as the horrific monsters like spiders, human-like monsters without legs, big demon dogs with no eyes and even a pile of ooze! There is this quota that you have to reach which is a small some of money that you get from selling the pieces of junk that you find. But if you don't reach the quota, you get fired! (shot into the vast abyss people call space). Lethal Company is purely based on it's cooperative factor meaning playing with others is the most efficient way of playing other than playing alone.

In my honest opinion, Lethal Company's traits sort of clash towards Phasmophobia. if you haven't played this game yet, then there is this terminal that you can use to oversee your teamates location aswell as the location of nearby entities. Because I say that Lethal Company is like Phasmophobia, in Phasmophobia if you're playing in multiplayer mode, you can use a computer in the van to look through cameras aswell as your teamates (but only of they're wearing a head camera). One of Lethal Company's aspects that is like Phasmophobia is their use of walkie-talkies. Both of these games have walkie-talkies that are used to communicate with people that are far away, but in Lethal Company you have to purchase walkie-talkies as for Phasmophobia you get one for free.

(...) For years to come, Lethal Company will be one of the first games that you would probably not find a cheap copy of. This game has been in production for many years now as said by the developer... And I respect that...

9/10
[Not everything is perfect but I could be seeing this game becoming a 10/10 because of any future updates or game changes to come]

Lethal Company is another indie horror game that doesn't follow the typical formula. Though its graphics aren't the greatest, they are certainly unique and are perfect for this type of game. The various planets are great, each with new environments, mechanics and most importantly entities. There are over fifteen entities to come across when exploring the abundance of facilities. Each one with a horrifying design and some even scarier sound affects. Each entity is fun to come across and makes for really innovative game play that isn't otherwise seen in other horror games. Another fun mechanic is the customisation of the character/ship. There is an abundance of items that can be utilised to decorate the interior of the ship and the character. The items that are used e.g radios, flashlights, spray cans etc are also a cool addition. Obtaining a certain amount of parts from each map can be a bit repetitive at times though. The lore is intriguing as well. The true standout of Lethal Company has to be its multiplayer. It's so fun playing Lethal Company with friends. Especially with all the entities inside the buildings, it will make for some memorable, terrifying and hilarious moments. With some amazing multiplayer and some terrifying moments, Lethal Company makes a great lasting impression. 7.5/10

This game is a treat. I keep coming back, the updates may be a little slow, but steady - it's made by 1 dev after all. They probably could have cashed out with how much money this game has made, but they're still working on new content. It's in a fantastically replayable state already, but the game's future remains promising.

Best with friends, but you (might) get lucky with a decent group in public lobbies.

The modding community is thriving, which helps a lot with the wait for new official content. I often play with 4-8 friends at a time with a mod tweaks here and there - it's a great experience.

This game is incredibly fun even in its current simplicity, I can't wait to see where it goes and I'm excited to follow its growth. It's also "easier" with a full group, but that's more to do with how the game itself is built - it's clearly made to be played with others, as the quota gets way too high for a single person to be able to fulfill.

Vanilla or modded, you're in for a really fun ride!

This game is so much fun, it is easily one of the best horror/multiplayer games I have played in a long time. It is genuinely terrifying and also very tense, especially when you cant tell if everyone else is dead. I would definitely recommend if you have friends to play with. The only slight problem I have is that when you get fired you lose everything, it would be nice if there was permanent progress like cosmetics, maybe permanent skins for the characters or even the ships. Another slight problem I have is the water, whenever you are interacting with water it is just a miserable experience, especially when you are stuck in it and cant get out but you arent drowning. But compared to everything else in the game these are just minor complaints. I would be nice for future updates to feature things like new maps that you can visit earlier in the game and being able to join a lobby at any point. Overall a fantastic game.

tldr; This game is Youtuber/Streamer bait and not actually very fun to play. Enemies do not have reasonable counter-play, often resulting in instadeath; scenarios that are difficult to learn from. Failures are extremely punishing as just one bad day, or unexpected instakill from around a corner, can often ruin the entire run. The game audio and voice chat are both poorly implemented; I'm often unable to tell what direction sounds are coming from, ambiance regions feel blocky and incohesive, and there is no noise suppression or gating of microphone audio. It just isn't a very fun experience for us even though we really want it to be.

The fun of the game is completely based on the interactions of the players. If your group of friends doesn't get scared easily or aren't in the habit of overreacting to everything, then the appeal will wear off super quick. 

Think of it like a card/board game you play at parties. It's about being dumb and laughing at dumb things with the added benefit of not having to clean anything up. 

If that stuff isn't your jam, then don't let the hype or streamer spam get to you and just give it a pass.

With 120 hours of fun experience I've got to say that this game is more than worth it. The Graphics might look unappealing but after you play a few rounds you realize that it fits perfectly for the games mood and overall style. A retro looking horror game where you have to bring out scrap from random facilities to sell them to a misterious company for money. During your expeditions you will find some data logs which uncover more and more about the games lore and this is what I love about this game. If you are a individual who loves to explore you can explore maps to find data logs and read them on the terminal for some extra lore. To whoever has a problem with an enemy then I've got to say yes. I can understand but if we take a bigger picture those enemies are just making the overall experience of this game a lot more appealing and fun. If there wouldn't be a challange for anyone then the game won't be anymore. But with this game there are always more and more challanges to be come over to. This is why RNG really carries this game. The different layout and monster combos really turn this repetitive game experience into a challanging and action full gameplay which I simply cannot get enough of.

Nutcrackers were the best addition the game and I love fighting them with the shovel :)
Still a better experience than working for Amazon IRL.

Vultures 1 is the debut studio album by the American hip hop superduo ¬•$, composed of rapper Kanye West and singer Ty Dolla Sign. It was released independently through West's YZY brand on February 10, 2024. The album features guest vocals from West's daughter North, Freddie Gibbs, YG, Quavo, Playboi Carti, Travis Scott, Bump J, Lil Durk, Rich the Kid, and Chris Brown. Production was primarily handled by West himself, alongside Digital Nas, JPEGMafia, Timbaland, 88-Keys, No I.D., Wheezy, Chrishan, Ojivolta, and Anthony Kilhoffer, among others. It serves as a follow-up to both artists' 2021 studio albums, Donda and Cheers to the Best Memories, also marking their third collaborative albums.

Horror in multiplayer almost never works. I think the best way to describe Lethal Company is [b]Horror Comedy[/b].

It alternates between hilarious moments when you friend walks into a mine while screaming because of a facehugger chomping on their head, and you being scared shitless by unfamiliar sounds in the darkness when you don't know your way out and you have no idea if anyone else is still alive. It's an absolute blast and one that I can only hope will continue receiving some love into the future to get to it's full potential.

As of v49--there's 2 (technically 3) ways to play this game but only 1 way to play it right.

[h2] COOP MODE - The Right Way To Play [/h2]
Up to you and 3 Dummies collect alot of Scrap, run away from or shovel gang alot of the Enemies; rinse and repeat. Def has alot of Comedy-Horror Vibes, alot of notes takin from SCP:CB when dealing with certain monsters. Alot of screaming, alot of fun; Good stuff. That Rock & Stone wholesome togetherness is here. (Wouldn't mind seeing some crossover content with DRG someday BTW.)

[h2] SOLO MODE - Help me Plz, the Bracken is Comi- [/h2]
It's just you, alot of running, alot of screaming, alot of dying, and none of the fun. The game suddenly becomes "shit your pants scary"--scarier then even a single night with Freddy. For record--If everyone dies, you lose everything you collected....."You are 'everyone' now".... You die, that's it, run's over.  

The only reason why you would ever solo is if your masochistic and doing a Solo Quota 10 Run...or you have no friends (ok, maybe you do but they don't have this game or they are not on.) It's good practice for staying alive but, yea, not fun.

[h2] MODDED MOD -- Thomas The Tank Engine is coming to kill me now. What is this; Sodor Fallout? [/h2]
The Third Way. For record on my part--I don't like modding. It's ether a hassle, corrupts the game files I'm trying to mod, and/or ultimately fixes a broken game that deserves no credit & wins the game awards. Is like using Steroids at the Olympics if you ask me. A game should stand on it's own two legs first before modding it. 

That being said; The game w/o mods is ok, I think. However, everyone and their grandma's grandma mods this game and it requires ether manual editing or the use of some outside-party website and an app that is sketch to me. The site is probably fine but it just doesn't sit well. Workshop support when? Maybe that mod site that DRG uses would work too. 

Some mods do fix or add quality of life like TTS Chat, Prox Radio, being able to buy Shotgun Shells, play YT vids on the TV....Lewdy Models....*Ahem* and other things. As a newcomer (and as anyone should do first)--I wanna get good at Vanilla Mode first before even installing a mod.

[h2] Overall Bottomline - tl;dr [/h2]
Give the game 2 airhorns out of 10 for Solo but 6 of 10 for Coop. Mods n/a. Hope to see this game improve and grow.

I'll be honest. I don't get the hype or the overwhelmingly positive reception.

I LOVE co-op games. I also enjoy games that offer more than your average horde shooters, competitive shooters, or other gameplay formulas that have been copy-pasted thousands of times.

I will admit that this game is cheap and not necessarily a bad game, but the overwhelmingly positive review score is an insane exaggeration, in my opinion.

Compared to other co-op giants such as Deep Rock Galactic, Outlast Trials, and even Left 4 Dead, this game's gameplay loop has the depth of a rain puddle. The first 4 or 5 runs are fun and can turn out interesting, but after that, you'll realize there is nothing more to this game than non-stop scavenger missions in uninteresting locations, with some enemies and jokey interactions thrown in.

I can definitely see and acknowledge that this game has a unique premise and design going for it, but I simply feel like the current review score is misleading.

----------------------------------------

[17-02-2024] Edit after more hours playing and seeing the game develop:

Although I still think that the overwhelmingly positive review score is a bit of an overexaggeration, I simply cannot deny that this game has a very compelling charm to it and I am therefore changing my review to positive. And even though the actual gameplay is still very flat on a surface level (imo), the variety in dangerous encounters (not to mention the immense amount of mods available for this game) really does spice up the overall experience. However, I would still not recommend this game to anyone looking for a single-player roguelite. The game is clearly and thoroughly crafted from the ground up to be enjoyed with others, whether they're friends or strangers.
